thread.section_title: Foreign and national political news and analysis - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: FTC reviewing VW's 'Clean Diesel' ads for fraudulent claims
thread.title_full: FTC reviewing VW's 'Clean Diesel' ads for fraudulent claims - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Michael Biesecker, Associated Press
title: FTC reviewing VW's 'Clean Diesel' ads for fraudulent claims
text: Photo: Biesecker, Michael, AP This is a framegrab from a Volkswagen commercial for a vehicle with their TDI Clean Diesel engine. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is investigating whether Volkswagen's "clean diesel" advertising claims amounted to a fraud on American consumers, adding a new avenue for regulators to punish the company for its deception. For years, the company aired memorable TV spots using terms such as “miraculous” to describe the car’s seemingly too-good-to-be-true balance of peppy acceleration, 40-mile-per-gallon gas mileage and low greenhouse gas emissions. The company has withdrawn those ads following last month’s admission it had engaged in an scheme to rig U.S. emissions tests. (Volkswagen/Youtube via AP) This is a framegrab from a Volkswagen commercial for a vehicle with... WASHINGTON (AP) — "Aren't diesels dirty?" asks the grandmother in the passenger seat of the gleaming new VW Golf SportWagen. This is a framegrab from a Volkswagen commercial for a vehicle with their TDI Clean Diesel engine. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is investigating whether Volkswagen's "clean diesel" advertising claims amounted to a fraud on American consumers, adding a new avenue for regulators to punish the company for its deception. For years, the company aired memorable TV spots using terms such as “miraculous” to describe the car’s seemingly too-good-to-be-true balance of peppy acceleration, 40-mile-per-gallon gas mileage and low greenhouse gas emissions. The company has withdrawn those ads following last month’s admission it had engaged in an scheme to rig U.S. emissions tests.
